Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Repair or replace damaged wooden structures or components
Situation2: A homeowner reports a damaged wooden deck, and the carpenter needs to repair or replace it to restore functionality
Story: My phone buzzed just as I was packing up my tools for the day. It was my younger sister, inviting me to join her and some friends for dinner at her favorite restaurant. She sounded excited, and I knew she wanted me there—not just as her brother, but as someone she could count on to show up and be part of her life. I promised her I’d try, but as soon as I hung up, another call came in. This time, it was a homeowner whose deck I’d inspected last week. The damage was worse than I thought, and he needed it fixed tonight before his family’s big gathering tomorrow. He was counting on me, and I could hear the urgency in his voice. I stood in my workshop, torn between the expectation to be a present, supportive brother and the responsibility to deliver quality work as a carpenter. My mind raced, weighing the disappointment my sister might feel if I didn’t show up against the trust the homeowner placed in me. The pressure from both sides pressed in, and I felt caught in the middle, unsure which role I should honor tonight.
